item.title: 10 Best Goalkeepers In UFL, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • UFL offers dynamic player ratings & updates based on real-life performances, enhancing gameplay authenticity.
  • Top goalkeepers like Alisson, ter Stegen, & Oblak excel in UFL with unique skills & reliability under pressure.
  • UFL constantly adapts, making it crucial for managers to stay ahead with top keeper choices.

UFL is changing the game in sports gaming, leaving behind the stale formula of yearly releases in favor of a dynamic and ever-evolving experience. With regular updates and real-time player rating adjustments, UFL stays true to the action on the pitch. If a goalkeeper is pulling off world-class saves week after week in real life, you can bet their in-game stats will reflect that. Just be ready for their price to rise as their reputation grows—building a championship-worthy squad is never easy, but that’s what makes it so rewarding.

No team is complete without a rock-solid presence between the posts. A great goalkeeper is more than just a last line of defense—they’re the backbone of your squad, commanding the box, pulling off clutch saves, and even kick-starting counterattacks with pinpoint distribution. This list will help players find the best shot-stoppers in UFL , whether looking for a reflex master, a penalty-saving specialist, or a sweeper-keeper who can play with their feet.

Since UFL is always adapting, so is this list. As updates roll out and real-life performances shift the rankings, we’ll keep you ahead of the curve. Ready to secure the goal with the very best keepers UFL has to offer? Let’s dive in!

10 Ederson

Rating: 86

  • CP: 116,000,000
  • RP: 92,000
  • Renaissance FC

Ederson’s 86 rating emphasizes his unique role as a ball-playing goalkeeper. Playing in 35 league matches, keeping 18 clean sheets, and contributing to City’s title-winning campaign with his shot-stopping ability and distribution from goal. Coupled with an 85% pass accuracy shows that Ederson can lead from the back.

In UFL , his pinpoint passing and composure under pressure make him indispensable for managers who love to build from the back. His ability to sweep behind the defense adds an extra layer of security.

9 Mike Maignan

Rating: 86

  • CP: 106,000,000
  • RP: 92,000
  • Cavalier FC

Mike Maignan’s 86 rating reflects his rise as one of Europe’s most dependable goalkeepers. Averaging 3.2 saves per game, Maignan was a key factor in Milan’s defensive success and 14 goalless games in league matches and 6 during the knockout stages in the Champions League.

In UFL , he offers a mix of sharp reflexes, solid positioning, and excellent distribution. Maignan’s confidence and leadership make him a reliable choice for managers seeking consistency in goal that won't break the bank.

8 Yann Sommer

Rating: 86

  • CP: 103,000,000
  • RP: 86,000
  • Team (Local): Renaissance FC

Yann Sommer’s 86 rating highlights his agility and quick reflexes. Playing in 26 league matches, keeping 11 clean sheets providing stability in Inter’s defense throughout the season, and averaging 3.5 saves per game, Sommer demonstrated his ability to make crucial stops under pressure, helping secure vital points for Inter.

In UFL , he’s an excellent choice for managers looking for a keeper who excels in high-pressure situations. Sommer’s ability to pull off incredible saves and his sharp decision-making makes him a reliable option for any squad.

7 Gianluigi Donnarumma

Rating: 86

  • CP: 109,000,000
  • RP: 96,000
  • Team (Local): Adidas FC

Gianluigi Donnarumma’s 86 rating highlights his raw talent and physical dominance. 15 clean sheets across 30 games helped Paris Saint-Germain secure the Ligue 1 title and a whopping 3.8 saves per game makes Donnarumma a key defensive player over the 23/24 season and definitely one to watch.

In UFL , his height and reflexes make him a nightmare for strikers in one-on-one situations. Donnarumma’s potential for growth ensures he’s a long-term investment for managers looking to build an unbeatable defense.

6 Yassine Bono

Rating 86

  • CP: 69,500,000
  • RP: 50,000
  • Team (Local): Sunset FC

Yassine Bounou’s 86 rating reflects his ability to shine under pressure. Averaging 3.5 saves per game, Bono was vital in maintaining Sevilla’s defensive solidity, making crucial interventions in high-pressure situations, and making several key saves throughout the Europa League knockout stages; including a crucial penalty save in the final to secure the title for Sevilla.

In UFL , his agility and knack for big saves make him a standout option. Bounou’s calm demeanor and excellent reactions ensure he’s ready for high-pressure scenarios, making him a favorite for knockout tournaments.

5 Marc-André ter Stegen

Rating: 88

  • CP: 157,000,000
  • RP: 125,000
  • Team (Local): Castle FC

Marc-André ter Stegen’s 88 rating underlines his status as a technically gifted goalkeeper. 21 clean sheets across 36 league matches makes it no surprise that ter Stegen is high on this list, with a whopping 4.2 saves per game and a strong command of the penalty area across several key moments throughout the season.

In UFL , ter Stegen shines with his exceptional distribution and ability to pull off acrobatic saves. He’s perfect for managers who value keepers capable of launching counterattacks while maintaining composure in tight games.

4 Jan Oblak

Rating: 88

  • CP: 133,000,000
  • RP: 110,000
  • Team (Local): Capital City FC

Jan Oblak’s 87 rating represents his consistency as a world-class shot-stopper. Oblak played in 33 league matches, keeping 14 clean sheets and providing a solid defensive presence that helped Atletico Madrid secure a top-four finish. A consistent all-rounder that always shows up when needed.

In UFL , Oblak’s reliability in handling crosses and making reflex saves makes him a fortress at the back. For managers who value defensive solidity above all, Oblak is a cornerstone of success.

3 Emiliano Martínez

Rating: 88

  • CP: 142,000,000
  • RP: 130,000
  • Team (Local): Adidas FC

Emiliano Martínez’s 88 rating reflects his rise as a clutch performer on the biggest stages. Emiliano Martínez had a 12 clean sheet record across 34 league games, which is not too bad but Martinez was pivotal for Aston Villa's semifinal run in the European Conference with 3.8 saves per game.

In UFL , he’s known for his commanding presence in the box and remarkable reflex saves. Martínez’s ability to handle penalties and pressure makes him a top pick for managers who love dramatic match-winning moments.

2 Alisson

Rating: 89

  • CP: 143,000,000
  • RP: 135,000
  • Team (Local): Titans FC

Alisson’s 89 rating highlights his exceptional all-around goalkeeping skills. Playing in 35 league matches, keeping 19 clean sheets, and providing stability in Liverpool’s defense throughout the season, helping secure a top-four finish. With an average of 3.3 saves per game, Alisson really shone during the Champions League with some crucial saves, including a penalty, in the round of 16.

In UFL , he excels in one-on-one situations, sweeping behind the defense, and distributing the ball accurately. Alisson’s blend of athleticism and decision-making ensures he’s a game-changer for managers who prioritize stability at the back.

1 Thibaut Courtois

Rating: 90

  • CP: 214,000,000
  • RP: 175,000
  • Team (Local): Titans FC

Thibaut Courtois’ 90 rating solidifies his reputation as one of the best goalkeepers in the world. This is a rating that definitely takes into account prior seasons, his 23/24 run was cut short in the early stages but he still managed 8 clean sheets and a 3.1 save average during that time.

In UFL , Courtois offers unmatched shot-stopping ability and dominance in aerial situations. His composure under pressure and incredible reflexes make him a must-have for managers seeking a reliable last line of defense.

item.title: 8 Best JRPGs With Multiple Protagonists, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Multiple protagonists in JRPGs create a rich narrative experience with unique perspectives and character development.
  • Games like Like A Dragon and Romancing SaGa 2 use multiple protagonists to explore dynasties, enriching gameplay.
  • Titles like Octopath Traveler and Persona Q blend individual narratives into a coherent overarching story, creating an engaging experience.

JRPGs are renowned for their captivating stories, unforgettable characters, and expansive worlds. When these games feature multiple protagonists, they offer a unique narrative structure, allowing players to experience different perspectives and delve into stories that may stand alone or interconnect, creating a rich and dynamic experience.

The best JRPGs with multiple protagonists are those that use this element to add variety and complexity to the plot. Each character, with distinct motivations and story arcs, complements the narrative while keeping players engaged throughout the game, making every journey memorable and unique.

8 Persona Q: Shadows Of The Labyrinth

A Meeting Of Persona 3 And 4 Main Characters

Although less popular than the main series, Persona Q: Shadows of The Labyrinth allows players to explore a unique story where protagonists and companions from Persona 3 and Persona 4 come together. For fans of the franchise, this is a rare chance to enjoy entertaining and fresh interactions between iconic characters.

The game offers the choice of playing as the protagonist from Persona 3 or Persona 4 , providing different perspectives on the unfolding story. Eventually, the narratives converge, bringing all characters together in a collaborative journey to overcome challenges and return to their respective worlds, making it an excellent crossover for enthusiasts of the series.

7 Octopath Traveler

Loosely Interconnected Stories In This Game

The gameplay of the first Octopath Traveler , as well as its sequel, stands out for allowing players to explore the game’s story through different character perspectives, choosing which one to play as. Each protagonist in the narrative has their own origin story and motivations.

Unfortunately, the plots of these characters remain largely self-contained, with each one having their own development arc and limited interactions with the others. However, the protagonists of Octopath Traveler are subtly connected by a common goal, which is usually unveiled during the final moments of the story and gameplay.

6 Romancing SaGa 2: Revenge Of The Seven

An Epic JRPG Through Generations

Developed by Square Enix, Romancing SaGa 2 introduces a unique dynastic succession system, placing players in control of a lineage of Avalon emperors. Each protagonist inherits abilities from their predecessors, allowing characters to grow stronger over time through a story that spans generations.

As a JRPG with multiple protagonists, the game delivers a dynamic and enriching experience. Changing protagonists diversifies gameplay while exploring the consequences of player choices on the kingdom. This blend of innovative and classic elements makes Romancing SaGa 2 a standout choice for fans of the genre.

5 Tales Of Xillia

A Journey With Two Distinct Protagonists

In Tales of Xillia , players can choose between Jude or Milla to experience the story, a mechanic that highlights the game as a standout JRPG with multiple protagonists. The choice affects scenes, battle themes, and the perspective of events when the group separates, delivering a unique and engaging experience.

Jude’s narrative focuses on personal growth, while Milla’s story ties directly to the central events of the plot. Their complementary arcs add depth to the narrative, encouraging multiple playthroughs to fully explore the intricate storylines. This replay value ensures Tales of Xillia offers a fresh perspective with additional content in subsequent runs.

4 Kingdom Hearts: Birth By Sleep

Three Interconnected Stories In This Game

Kingdom Hearts: Birth by Sleep features a unique narrative structure split between three protagonists: Terra, Ventus, and Aqua. Each character has a separate campaign, exploring different events and locations, providing a deeper understanding of the overarching story. Completing all campaigns and collecting the Xehanort’s Report unlocks an additional fourth campaign.

The game stands out for weaving these stories into a cohesive narrative, where each journey plays a crucial role. The Final Mix version adds a Secret Episode focused on Aqua, requiring specific criteria to unlock. This extra campaign further enriches the game’s storytelling, solidifying its place as a beloved entry in the franchise.

3 Like A Dragon: Infinite Wealth

Iconic Protagonists Unite In This JRPG

One of the standout features of Like A Dragon: Infinite Wealth , aside from its engaging gameplay and humor, is the ability to experience the story from two different perspectives. Players follow the series' new protagonist, Ichiban Kasuga, alongside Kazuma Kiryu.

The narratives unfold simultaneously, with players exploring Hawaii as one character while the other remains in Yokohama. This dual-perspective approach enhances the JRPG experience, even though the concept isn't new to the franchise, as multiple protagonists have been a recurring element in previous entries.

2 Final Fantasy 6

JRPG With Two Incredible Protagonists

While Final Fantasy 6 occasionally presents the story from varying perspectives, Terra Branford and Celes Chere stand out as the true protagonists of this JRPG. Terra drives the initial narrative, with her magical powers playing a pivotal role in the fight against the Gestahlian Empire, emphasizing her significance in the war.

Celes takes the lead during the World of Ruin, the game’s final act, after Kefka’s devastating actions reshape the world. In this segment, players explore early dungeons with her while uncovering information about their missing companions. This protagonist shift enriches the storytelling, cementing Final Fantasy 6 as a classic within the genre.

1 Live A Live

Narratives Across Different Eras Of Humanity

At first, the story of Live A Live appears to be quite contained, with each of the seven characters living in distinct periods of human history and their narratives seemingly unconnected. However, upon completing all chapters, new content is unlocked, revealing multiple connections between the stories presented in the anthology.

This structure allows Live A Live stands out as a JRPG with multiple protagonists, allowing players to explore varied mechanics and incredible narratives. Each character introduces unique gameplay elements, contributing to a distinct experience that culminates in an epic conclusion where all characters unite for a final battle against the main antagonist.

item.title: What to Expect From The Last of Us Franchise in 2025
item.description:
News about what's next for The Last of Us has been on many fans' minds, and Naughty Dog's surprise announcement at The Game Awards was not what many expected. Naughty Dog didn't announce a new chapter of The Last of Us , but instead revealed a brand-new IP. Intergalactic: The Heretic Prophet is a huge departure from The Last of Us . This time around, Naughty Dog is exploring an 80s-inspired retro-future that teases a melee focus.

While this may not be the announcement fans of The Last of Us were hoping for, that doesn't mean there aren't exciting things on the horizon for the franchise. The announcement of Intergalactic: The Heretic Prophet doesn't mean The Last of Us Part 3 is off the table. The wait may just be a little while longer. However, 2025 still has plenty in store for The Last of Us fans.

Despite No New Game, The Last of Us Still Has a Busy Year Ahead

  • The Last of Us Part 2 Remastered on PC
  • The Last of Us season 2 premiering on HBO

Even though a third Last of Us game was not announced at the Game Awards, there is a silver lining found in The Last of Us Part 2 Remastered coming to PC in April. Via Steam and the Epic Games Store, PC players will now get to experience The Last of Us Part 2 at its very best. Now, The Last of Us Part 2 Remastered gets to find an even bigger audience, which could bode well for the possibility of a Part 3 in the future, but that remains to be seen.

The Last of Us Part 2 Remastered will launch on PC on April 3, 2025.

Season 2 of TLOU Series Premieres in 2025

While there has to be an official release date locked in, HBO has confirmed that season 2 of The Last of Us will premiere sometime in the spring of 2025. The live-action adaptation of the Naughty Dog IP had a strong first season that expanded the franchise's reach, and its impending second season is set to arrive in the first half of the year. There may not be an official release date yet, but the launch date of The Last of Us Part 2 Remastered on PC could be a hint.

Neil Druckmann and Craig Mazin have confirmed that season 2 of TLOU will have seven episodes. According to the co-writers, Part 2 's story will span over multiple seasons.

TLOU Part 2 Remastered Could Give Insight Into TLOU Season 2’s Release Date

The second season of The Last of Us having a spring release target feels far more intentional now. With April being The Last of Us Part 2 Remastered 's PC launch date, it would make a lot of sense for the HBO series to premiere around the same time. Of course, this is just speculation, and nothing has been made official, but releasing the two in close proximity would be ideal from a marketing perspective.

A Third Chapter of TLOU Has Yet to Be Revealed

Although hope for The Last of Us Part 3 continues, Naughty Dog has made it clear with its newly announced IP that its post-apocalyptic franchise may not be a top priority right now. Part 3 is still a possibility, but it seems like 2025 will not be the year an announcement gets made.

Of course, surprises could happen, but the compelling change of form Naughty Dog is taking with Intergalactic: The Heretic Prophet is intriguing. The developer leaving the grounded nature of The Last of Us and Uncharted and opting for heavy sci-fi is exciting, even if it's not exactly what was expected. So, there is no new The Last of Us game right now, but fans of the HBO series and PC gamers have plenty to look forward to.

item.title: Best PS5 Games On PlayStation Plus Extra & Premium (December 2024)
item.description:
In June 2022 in North America, Sony launched a revamped version of PlayStation Plus that combines the previous model with PS Now. Split into three tiers, subscribers who invest in PS Plus Extra or Premium gain access to a wide selection of PlayStation games. While the library has hundreds of PS4 titles, it also includes quite a few PlayStation 5 releases, something PS Now did not offer.

With each new month of additions, PS Plus Extra adds a couple of PS5 titles, ensuring the library continues to expand. So far, the selections have been decent, and they have arguably been getting better as the current generation progresses. Consequently, what are the best PS5 games on PS Plus Extra ?

Updated December 16, 2024: This month's PS Plus Essential games are all pretty great, although one title stands above the rest and warrants a special mention.

Also, on December 17, the PS Plus Extra games will be added to the service. The selection is quite decent, even if an argument could be made that it lacks a really big PS5 title that is universally loved. Still, the following projects are exciting:

  • A Space for the Unbound
  • Coffee Talk
  • FIST: Forged in Shadow Torch
  • Forspoken (not beloved, but a good option for a subscription service)
  • Jurassic World Evolution 2
  • Sonic Frontiers

The rankings are not based solely on quality. For example, new PS5 PS Plus games will be (initially) mentioned first, along with titles that are part of Essential's monthly lineup.

1 It Takes Two (PS Plus Essential For December 2024)

An All-Time Great Co-Op Game

PS Plus Essential's final month of 2024 includes a pretty good lineup of PS5 games, all of which are worth adding to every library. Positioned as a big alternative to Pokemon , Temtem 's star has faded a bit since its original release, but its positives are still notable enough to justify a mention. If somebody is craving a harder monster-collecting/fighting game, they will get what they are looking for in Temtem . The game looks great too. Dark Descent is XCOM with Aliens , a combo that works pretty well. The tactics genre can be a tough sell to the uninitiated, but the presence of an identifiable IP might help bring over a few people who otherwise would not consider these types of releases. Dark Descent serves as an OK entry point as well, although it is fairly difficult.

Finally, the December 2024 lineup has It Takes Two , one of the best co-op games of the 2020s. Just to be clear, this is not a single-player game that supports multiplayer, but rather a pure co-op experience that requires two people. The gameplay revolves entirely around cooperative play, and the story also features a married couple who are on the verge of divorce. So, communication and teamwork are narratively and mechanically important, combining to create a well-rounded experience that is thematically consistent. Blending puzzles and platforming, It Takes Two shakes up its gameplay loop pretty frequently too, with most stages introducing fresh ideas.

2 Two Point Campus

Back To University

Two Point Studios has a knack for creating life-consuming simulation games, and Two Point Campus builds smartly on Two Point Hospital 's formula. As implied by the title, players are put in charge of running a university, which comes with plenty of decisions, both easy and hard.

Two Point Campus throws quite a lot of ideas, options, and mechanics at players, which can be overwhelming, especially for those who did not play its predecessor. However, it is all tight together with a lighthearted tone and solid instructions that should help beginners get started. Two Point Campus can be a massive time-sink, especially due to its sandbox mode that feels basically endless.

3 The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt

Brilliant Writing, World-Building, Characters, And Nearly Everything Else

Released for the PS4 in 2015, The Witcher 3 made its way to the PS5 in 2022, and both versions are available on PS Plus. While the original iteration is still worth playing today, the PS5 update comes with an array of improvements and changes that, overall, amount to the definitive version of The Witcher 3 , at least on consoles. Despite looking far better on current-gen hardware, this is still ultimately the same experience; therefore, people who already played through the 50+ hour campaign might not find much reason to sit through the same story for a second time. However, anyone who has yet to jump into CD Projekt Red's masterpiece can now do so with far improved visuals, quality-of-life adjustments, and quicker load times.

Plainly put, The Witcher 3 is right up there with the greatest RPGs and open-world games of all time. While the main plot is good but not necessarily mind-blowing, the secondary content is regularly fantastic, telling gripping self-contained stories driven by well-developed NPCs and a fully realized world. The combat takes some getting used to and tends to be slightly polarizing, but it fits Geralt's background and personality well.

4 Remnant 2

One Of The Best Co-Op Soulslikes (Especially For Shooter Fans)

Although hardly exhaustive, PS Plus has a respectable selection of Soulslike games. For the most part, these releases tend to lean heavily into close-quarters combat, with mage builds being viable in some projects; however, few games prioritize ranged action. Gunfire's Remnant series is the definitive exception that blends the core Soulslike experience with third-person shooter gunplay, delivering experiences that bring out the best in both genres. While the first entry is not available, Sony's service has the 2023 sequel, which surpasses its predecessor in most key areas.

Remnant 2 feels big. The campaign is divided into worlds, with each one being fairly large, grandiose, and unique. Even the boss battles emphasize scale, including a particularly inspired encounter against a cube. Impactful and satisfying, the combat is accessible but challenging, and it is enhanced by build variety courtesy of archetypes and weapon modifications. As great as a solo run can be, Remnant 2 is made for co-op.

5 Ratchet & Clank: Rift Apart

A Pitch-Perfect Ratchet & Clank Adventure

Ratchet & Clank: Rift Apart was one of the first projects to truly come across as a next-generation experience, and the game is still among the console's standard-setters. Insomniac has been on fire over the last few years, and while Spider-Man has hogged most of the spotlight, the studio regularly produces the goods whenever it returns to its other flagship IP.

Rift Apart is, fundamentally, just another Ratchet & Clank adventure that delivers exactly what most fans have come to expect from the franchise. Along with stunning graphics, the game has fast-paced and satisfying gunplay, enjoyable platforming, lavish worlds, and charming characters. Although not lacking in new ideas, including the introduction of a second playable character, Rift Apart mainly seeks to perfect the formula rather than reinvent it. The result is a polished, confident, and delightful third-person shooter.

6 Ghost Of Tsushima: Director's Cut

Immersive And Gorgeous Open-World PS5 Game

A highlight of the PS4's final main year, Ghost of Tsushima quickly made its way to the PS5, offering a native version that comes packed with the expansion. Sucker Punch's epic samurai adventure is a technological tour de force, delivering visuals that are consistently stunning. A lot has been stated about the graphics, but GoT 's brilliance goes well beyond just a pretty exterior. An occasionally frustrating camera aside, the combat combines dodging, parrying, crowd management, ranged options, stealth, and stances to create an impressively deep system that is nevertheless accessible.

Narratively, GoT mostly hits the mark, even if the overall story does not hold too many surprises. With the Mongols taking over Tsushima Island, a samurai named Jin sets out to find allies, rescue his master, and reclaim their home. Most of the campaign is framed through Jin's companions, who are generally more interesting than the protagonist. While following a fairly standard structure for the genre, the open-world benefits from consistently enjoyable side quests that emphasize the "common" people's struggle to survive in this post-war setting.

7 Returnal

Intense And Addictive Roguelike Shooter

Housemarque's Returnal is a sci-fi epic about Selene, a space traveler who visits a strange planet and becomes ensnared in a time loop. This plot point serves as narrative justification for the third-person shooter's roguelike structure; as Selene explores Atropos' six biomes, her demise will signal a return to the beginning.

Returnal has fantastic gameplay, which is hardly surprising considering the studio's previous releases like Alienation . The story builds an engrossing sense of mystery while cleverly diving into Selene's history and mental state.

8 Demon's Souls

An Impressive Remake Of A PS3 Classic

When the PlayStation 5 debuted, Bluepoint's Demon's Souls remake was the main reason to pick up the console. Since then Sony's system has welcomed quite a few great projects, but this launch title continues to be one of the PS5's crowning achievements.

FromSoftware's 2009 original is also on PS Plus Premium, and as game-changing as that PS3 classic is, the remake's improved gameplay and enhanced environments make it the version most worth playing on the subscription service.

9 Monster Hunter Rise

Fun Solo, Incredible Co-Op

Monster Hunter Rise started life on the Nintendo Switch, before eventually making its way to other ecosystems. While very popular in general, Capcom's franchise is still relatively niche and can be intimidating for newcomers who have yet to hunt their first monster. Consequently, World and Rise seemed to be designed with the specific purpose of lowering the barrier for entry, providing an accessible experience that still preserves the typical Monster Hunter experience that long-time fans have come to expect. As the easiest core title in the series, Rise incorporates a relatively short "story" that teaches beginners the basics, all the while allowing veterans to skip this crash course and jump right into the Hub quests that are the real meat of the game.

Monster Hunter Rise is addictive, time-consuming, and an absolute blast. Now, the gameplay loop is pretty basic: hunt, loot, craft, hunt, loot, craft, and repeat for eternity. However, the combat offers a ton of customization options, including 14 weapon types that feel completely different from each other and require dozens upon dozens of hours to master. While the village story missions are single-player, the Hub quests support co-op, which is generally the "ideal" way to experience a hunt. That said, Rise is a blast even when played solo.

10 Animal Well

Puzzle-Metroidvania With Style

A pleasant surprise, Animal Well is an indie Metroidvania with a strong artistic identity, responsive platforming, and clever puzzles. Beyond the atmospheric visuals, the latter brain-teasers are the game's main selling point, and every screen is a puzzle that requires utilizing a small assortment of tools in inspired ways to unlock doors and avoid threats (be it intimidating crows or a kangaroo). Putting aside fireworks that can stun or eliminate enemies, Animal Well is pretty much devoid of combat, with even boss fights being essentially puzzles with added steps and on a more epic scale.

While not extremely long, Animal Well is quite difficult in a few ways. More often than not, the puzzles require thinking outside the box, especially after the first hour of the campaign. Consequently, they can occasionally bring progression to a screeching halt, although they are satisfying to solve. The game does not provide much direction on where to go, leaving players to their own devices. That said, the map is quite detailed and helpful. Even if it might not be the biggest name ever, Animal Well is undoubtedly among the best PS5 PS Plus games and a must-play for anyone into puzzles or Metroidvanias.

11 Dead Island 2

A Gorefest Romp Through Zombie-Infested LA

Who does not enjoy slashing zombies to bits? Or, blasting them to smithereens? Dead Island 2 indulges in excess, delivering a consistently entertaining romp through a Los Angeles that has seen better days. The gameplay loop is quite straightforward, dropping players into semi-open but relatively linear areas and mostly just letting them kill everything that moves. Sure, there are some side quests, progression, and slayer classes, but they are not the focus or even a big part of the equation. No, Dead Island 2 is entirely about its combat and gore system.

Sometimes, simplicity is the best policy, and this sequel focuses on its strengths and minimizes any distractions. Consequently, if the gameplay does not click with someone within the first two hours or so, Dead Island 2 might not be for them. Conversely, if it clicks, it really clicks.

Dead Island 2 supports co-op.

12 Dave The Diver

Great Genre Blender With A Quirky Sense Of Humor

Dave the Diver follows, well, Dave as he dives into a magical sea in search of fish that can be turned into sushi for a restaurant he opened with a couple of friends. During the day, players explore the Blue Hole in search of living ingredients, and they have to make certain choices before they dive into the cold water. For one, Dave can only carry a limited loadout, meaning he has to preemptively pick between equipment suited for different fish, not knowing what he might find in the ever-changing Blue Hole. The daily dives can produce jaw-dropping vistas along with genuine terror (for Dave, the game is not remotely scary) and the occasional boss fight.

The management side of things also works well, even if it is a bit stripped down compared to games dedicated to the genre. Players have a fair degree of control over the restaurant's processes, including hiring staff to ensure things keep running smoothly. Dave the Diver is not the greatest management sim out there, but it complements the exploration side of things well to create a satisfying whole.

13 Rogue Legacy 2

Roguelike With Great Combat And Visuals

On the surface, the sequel to 2013's influential roguelite might not seem to take all that many risks as it largely sticks to the same core formula; however, Rogue Legacy 2 plays out like a perfected version of the original, which was and still is fantastic. As before, players are randomly assigned a class as they head into massive levels in search of loot and bosses. When death comes calling, they can pick from three new characters who will have different classes and personality traits. While they must start exploring from scratch, players can use their acquired loot to purchase upgrades, so they are not constantly returning to zero.

Rogue Legacy 2 emphasizes the differences between its classes way more than its predecessor, to the point that each one feels completely unique. Simply trying out the various options is fun, especially since most classes are fairly complex and take a while to master. Variety is also provided through the many traits, relics, and upgrades, all of which can greatly alter a build or run. The stages are expansive, ambitious, and detailed, ending with memorable boss fights that will test anyone's skills.

14 Doom Eternal

Intense FPS With No Dull Moments

Premium subscribers can check out the classics, starting from the 1993 original release and concluding with Doom 3 . Meanwhile, Doom Eternal is part of the Extra tier, along with its predecessor. Id Software knocked 2016's Doom completely out of the park, and the developer could have simply opted to rethread the exact same ground for the sequel; thankfully, Doom Eternal carves its own identity.

While still ultimately the Doom everyone knows and loves, this entry shakes things up by emphasizing the Doom Slayer's range of motion, even including things like a grappling hook. These abilities work beautifully within combat, providing players with more options than ever before. Even with a fairly forgiving dodge function, Doom Eternal still packs a considerable punch, especially since ammo is reasonably limited. The campaign does include a few polarizing platforming and traversal sections, but they do not take much away from the overall experience.

15 Humanity

Fascinating Puzzle Game

Debuting directly on PS Plus Extra, Humanity might not make as wide of a Day 1 splash as Stray , but the puzzle game is nonetheless a big get for Sony's service. Cast as a dog that must shepherd humans across dozens upon dozens of levels, players spend their time setting up directions to try and keep the crowd safely moving along. Although this might sound simple in theory, Humanity consistently introduces new mechanics, ideas, and options to maintain a steady challenge.

Ultimately, this 2023 release is an acquired taste that won't hit the spot with everyone; however, any fans of puzzle games should give it a look. Humanity has an eye-catching look, deceptively deep gameplay, and surprisingly intriguing themes, especially for its genre.

16 The Plucky Squire

A Day One Delight

OK, this one is slightly premature since The Plucky Squire has just come out, so this recommendation is based on limited playtime. Nevertheless, these types of Day One PS Plus debuts are rare and exciting, especially since this project attracted some hype in the lead-up to its release. As a fairly small indie release, The Plucky Squire was likely to be one of those games that many people would postpone trying until it was available on a subscription service; consequently, launching directly on PS Plus could give the platformer a boost in terms of exposure and positive press.

The Plucky Squire blends 2D and 3D action, with players exploring a storybook and the real world. This concept is neat and lends itself to an inspired presentation that oozes creativity and imagination. While platforming takes center stage, the game also incorporates puzzles and combat, so there is variety as well.

17 Night In The Woods

A Powerful Stroll Through Possum Springs

Night in the Woods immerses players in Possum Springs, a fairly typical small town that happens to consist of anthropomorphic animals. After a frustrating stint at college, Mae returns home and quickly settles into a routine, which mostly involves hanging out with old friends and exploring the town. While packed with silliness and boasting a slice of life tone at times, Night in the Woods dives fairly deep into its characters, and that goes beyond Mae. Cute animal designs aside, the story is defined by very human personalities who act in ways that make sense, and players get to make decisions that impact the narrative's flow.

As far as platformers are concerned, Night in the Woods ' gameplay is quite unremarkable, but it mostly feels fine and gets the job done. Ultimately, the focus is on the characters and their relationships, although there is an element of mystery as well. The 2017 game is fairly well known by this point, but if someone has yet to give it a try, they should take up the chance while it is on PS Plus Extra.

18 Uncharted: Legacy Of Thieves Collection

Naughty Dog's Two-Part Conclusions To An All-Time Great Franchise

PS Plus Extra launched with the PS4 versions of Uncharted 4: A Thief's End and The Lost Legacy , but the PS5's Legacy of Thieves Collection was added as part of the subscription service's March 2023 lineup. Now, the last-generation iterations are still absolutely fantastic, comparing favorably with most titles released over the last 5 years. Consequently, the "remaster" package does not bring too many changes, although the ones that are implemented make enough of a difference to establish the Legacy of Thieves Collection as the definitive way to experience these two stories.

Fueled by the power of the PS5, Uncharted 4 and The Lost Legacy now support multiple performance modes, allowing players to decide whether to prioritize 4K or 60 fps. The visuals have also been tweaked ever so slightly to give both games an overall cleaner and more immersive presentation. These improvements enhance two titles that were already considered masterpieces.

19 Kena: Bridge Of Spirits

A Rare Example Of A PS5 AA Game

AA gaming has been on the decline since the end of the PS3 era, and only a handful of modern releases fall within the bracket. However, a couple of projects do try to walk the line between indie and triple-A, with Kena: Bridge of Spirits serving as a prime example. Ember Lab's action-adventure title is visually impressive by any metric, dropping players into a fully realized fantasy world that has some gorgeous locations. In fact, the art style and special effects are arguably the game's strongest features.

That said, the rest of the experience is by no means underwhelming. Gameplay-wise, Kena is cut from the same bow-wielding cloth as Tomb Raider and Horizon Forbidden West , although it also mixes in some staff-themed melee attacks. While somewhat repetitive, the combat is generally fun and surprisingly challenging, particularly when it comes to the campaign's bosses. Alongside battles, the game relies heavily on puzzles and exploration, both of which are handled well.

20 Inscryption

Innovative Horror Game

At a glance, Inscryption might appear to be a fairly typical card-battler, albeit one with a darker aesthetic than the norm for the genre. And, in some ways, the game is just that, but there is so much more to this package than meets the eye. Inscryption 's card system might not hold too many surprises for people familiar with tabletop projects, but it is generally well-executed and addictive in a way that only these types of games seem to be.

Structured as a roguelite, players find themselves going up against a rather strange figure and a host of other opponents as they seek to win a series of matches. Each victory rewards new cards and upgrades, but multiple losses will send players back to square one. Inscryption does not stop at just a compelling battle system, and the game encourages players to explore beyond the table to piece together their circumstances. Yes, this is a card game with a story, and it is well done.

item.title: Skip Bo Mobile Codes (December 2024)
item.description:
Quick Links

  • All Skip Bo Codes
  • How to Redeem Codes in Skip Bo Mobile

Skip Bo Mobile is an exciting card game with both campaign and multiplayer modes. Although the cards resemble UNO cards, the rules of the game are different, so the game is quite interesting and unique. As in almost any mobile game, Skip Bo has a currency for which you can buy a variety of items. Fortunately, there are many codes in the game that will give you a bunch of Coins.

Updated December 16, 2024, by Artur Novichenko: Many new codes are ready to use and you can find them in the list of working Skip Bo codes below. You can get a lot of coins with them, so don't miss this chance.

How to Redeem Codes in Skip Bo Mobile

In mobile games, it is very important for players to be able to find where to redeem codes. Fortunately, in Skip Bo, redeeming codes is very simple, as you can see from these instructions:

  • Go to the Shop tab. This is the button in the lower right corner of the screen.
  • In the Shop, you will see offers to buy Coins and below them the Gift Code field. Click on it.
  • Enter or paste a code from our list of current codes.
  • Click Redeem to get your rewards.

Try to redeem all current codes as soon as possible because they expire very quickly, and you will not be able to receive rewards for them.

Skip Bo Mobile is available on iOS and Android.
